required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: High-flow Nasal Cannula Oxygenation Decrease Hypoxia in Sedated Gastrointestinal Endoscopes in Obesity
clinical_study.official_title: High-flow Nasal Cannula Oxygenation Decrease Hypoxia in Sedated Gastrointestinal Endoscopes in Obesity: a Randomized Multicenter Clinical Trial

collaborator.agency: Shanghai Tongji Hospital, Tongji University School of Medicine
Shanghai Oriental Hospital, Tongji University School of Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: Hypoxia is the most common adverse event during gastrointestinal endoscopes sedated with propofol and sufentanil, especially in obese people. In the present study, high-flow nasal cannula oxygenation will be utilized in order to reduce the incidence of hypoxia among obesity.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Patients will be followed for the duration of hospital stay, an expected average of 2 hours]

secondary_outcome.measure: The incidence of subclinical respiratory depression
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Patients will be followed for the duration of hospital stay, an expected average of 2 hours
Patients will be followed for the duration of hospital stay, an expected average of 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: (SpO2 < 75% for any duration or 75% < SpO2 < 90% for >/=60 s)

secondary_outcome.measure: Other adverse events include other adverse events recorded by tools proposed by the World Society of Intravenous Anesthesia International Sedation Task Force and HFNC supportive oxygen therapy-related adverse events.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Patients will be followed for the duration of hospital stay, an expected average of 2 hours

arm_group.description: Oxygen(up to 6L/min) supplied with a regular nasal catheter
Oxygen(up to 60L/min) supplied with high-flow nasal cannula

intervention.description: Oxygen is supplied with a high-flow nasal cannula oxygenation device#the flow is up to 60L/min
Oxygen is supplied with a regular nasal cannula #the flow is up to 6L/min

overall_official.affiliation: Renji Hospital, Shanghai Jiaotong University, Shanghai, China

facility.name: Renji hospital, School of Medicine, Shanghai Jiaotong University

responsible_party.investigator_title: Vice Chair of the Department of Anesthesiology
